posts.text:
feckingmorons : thirdgen: vygramul: What it's been described as is not terribly unreasonable, but it wouldn't surprise me if it has details that are over the top. But being able to transport your gun from PA to VT without having to worry about NY being dicks about it seems quite reasonable.
You've been allowed to do that since 1986.
Any number of people have been arrested at JFK when their airline had problems and they were required to pick up their checked bags with guns inside.
They hadn't intended to touch their bags when they checked them in at home until they were in VT (or some other state that doesn't have overreaching gun laws) but flight delays or mechanical problems made the airline give them their checked bag during their 'broken journey' as the airlines call it.
They "Firearm inside" tag the airline puts on it alerted Port Authority Police who arrested the travellers.
See also http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/0​1/18/traveling-mans-gun-arrest-appeale​d-supreme-court.html
The man was involuntary deplaned in NJ and given his luggage. He was arrested for having a gun in his luggage. Something perfectly legal in his origin, desired destination and under federal law. The criminal charges were eventually dropped but he couldn't sue for false arrest or having his gun seized.
A friend getting arrested at JFK for this exact thing, several years before I went to Law School, is the reason I knew about the traveler's exception.
You're right, PAPD doesn't give a crap about this law. My buddy was held for a few hours, and they took his guns. The process to get the guns back cost more than the guns were worth. A lawsuit would also cost more than it would be worth.

posts.text:
Jim_Callahan : I mean... it's just license reciprocity. Literally the most common form of federalism since forever.
This is the same reason you can marry someone in Kansas, drive to Nebraska, and yet somehow you're still married and still legally allowed to drive the car. Licenses and contracts are typically supposed to cross state lines to at least some extent.
The part that the NRA assholes aren't going to like is that this is going to fairly quickly result in CCPs having the same federal oversight and standardization as drivers' licenses, too. Wyoming can basically kiss its 'shall issue' permits with no training requirement goodbye.
No way the NRA agrees to background checks in support of national reciprocity.
They have already politicized the issue in a very blatant attempt to get zero background checks/constitutional carry into law via national reciprocity.
Everyone, even Trump, understands what they are attempting.
They will fail.

Ow! That was my feelings! : feckingmorons: Ow! That was my feelings!: So, the real question is...
Will gun owners accept national background checks in exchange for national reciprocity?
The NRA already has and will continue to say no.
I say yes.
No, that isn't the question at all. The NICS check to purchase a gun from an FFL is completely different than the state's fingerprint based FBI history records check required for a concealed weapons permit.
Two different checks, two different things.
If you buy a gun from an FFL you have to have an NCIS check (unless your state decides to do its own more thorough one the NICS approves of).
You don't have to get a concealed weapons permit if you don't want one. If you do that is completely different form, it doesn't go to the NICS, it is done by each state individually there is no option for them to have the FBI do it directly (they do have the FBI check your prints, but they pay a fee for that).
Two completely different things.
That isn't even a good effort.
I'd be insulted by your lack of effort, if I cared.

Yes, because the law stops at the state lines. Once those borders are rendered moot legislators will be free and clear to change those laws. And remember, it only takes one state.

olorin604 : feckingmorons: Ow! That was my feelings!: feckingmorons: Ow! That was my feelings!: No way the NRA agrees to background checks in support of national reciprocity.
All concealed weapons permits require a background check already. All require fingerprints sent to the FBI. Everyone, including the NRA, thing that is just spiffy.
Nope. You are incorrect. Some States are 'constitutional carry'.
Wyoming residents don't need a permit to carry a concealed carry if they can legally own a gun (other states too, I listed them above, ctrl-f Vermont and you'll easily find the list)
However a Wyoming resident CAN get a concealed weapon permit. If he wants to come to Florida and carry his gun he willl need one. Wyoming permits are valid in Florda and Florida permit are valid in Wyoming.
Just because a permit isn't required in a Constitutional Carry state does not necessarily mean they are not available.
A qualified individual must: (1) be eligible to possess, transport, or receive a firearm under federal law; (2) carry a valid photo identification document; and (3) carry a valid concealed carry permit issued by, or be eligible to carry a concealed firearm in, his or her state of residence.
https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-co​ngress/house-bill/38?q=%7B"search"%3A%​5B"concealed+carry+reciprocity+act"%5D​%7D
Not a lawyer but doesn't that "or be eligible..." mean that the actual permit is not needed if you are from a constitutional carry state.
The summary is too brief for this. You have to read the entire bill. Here is a more clear except that say you have to have the permit.
Notwithstanding any provision of the law of any State or political subdivision thereof (except as provided in subsection (b)) and subject only to the requirements of this section, a person who is not prohibited by Federal law from possessing, transporting, shipping, or receiving a firearm, who is carrying a valid identification document containing a photograph of the person, and who is carrying a valid license or permit which is issued pursuant to the law of a State and which permits the person to carry a concealed firearm or is entitled to carry a concealed firearm in the State in which the person resides, may possess or carry a concealed handgun (other than a machinegun or destructive device) that has been shipped or transported in interstate or foreign commerce, in any State that- (emphasis mine)
Damn good for you for going to the source rather than reading talking points.

My state allows both in person and online training. I am former military so I've been formerly trained in weapon use. I inquired which training I should take and was told to just click through the online. Literally. Just click through so the log shows I hit each page.
Not being one to game the system I read the material, at least the parts of it that were copied from the state statutes directly. Everything else was full of mistakes. Broken sentences, misspelled, sections that just didn't make any sense.
But I completed it and was able to shoot 10 holes at 10 yards into a piece of paper so I'm able to carry just about anywhere I want in my state. I even have a signed passing grade on it.
This really is like that story about the school posted here yesterday where they were graduating kids that didn't even show up.
This needs to be taken more seriously. The training needs to be accredited to prove that people aren't just going through the motions.

posts.text:
Ow! That was my feelings! : So, the real question is...
Will gun owners accept national background checks in exchange for national reciprocity?
The NRA already has and will continue to say no.
I say yes.
A) you might mean "universal background checks"
B) most states run you through a better background check for a CPL than the feds do for a purchase - states can deny you a CPL for misdemeanors that the feds don't care about - e.g. in my area, spitting on the sidewalk is disorderly conduct, and will make you ineligible to get a carry license for 7 or 8 years.
C) how you get the gun doesn't matter in this situation. If you're a person that can't legally possess and carry a gun, you can't get a CPL, so you aren't eligible for any of the benefits this bill provides because it requires you to meet all requirements in your home state and have a carry license.

posts.text:
feckingmorons : f150: Is this not a national back ground check that all states have? If you're deemed sane enough to have a gun carry permit in one state, why would anyone be deemed unfit to carry in the state next door when travelling?
/canuck
//seriously, I don't know why...
Each state can regulate but not completely ban guns.
To get a permit in all the states that I know you have to submit finger prints to the police who send them to the FBI to see if you're a criminal. If you're a criminal no permit.
But the training, both hands on and classroom varies from state to state. Some states limit what kind of guns you can carry.
I have a Florida permit, it is accepted by many states and Florida has reciprocity with and accepts most states permits too. I can drive up to (but not into) New York state without doing anything differently. NYS doesn't recognize Florida's permit (or anyone else's for that matter) so I can't carry a gun in NYS. I can't get a NYS permit because I don't live there. So I have to detour around NYS if I want to carry my gun on a trip to Vermont.
I don't know why NYS is paranoid about people from Pennsylvania or Florida who have passed an FBI background check, but NYS is weird. I like NY, but it is weird.
A qualified individual must: (1) be eligible to possess, transport, or receive a firearm under federal law; (2) carry a valid photo identification document; and (3) carry a valid concealed carry permit issued by, or be eligible to carry a concealed firearm in, his or her state of residence.
https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-c​o​ngress/house-bill/38?q=%7B"search"%3A%​5B"concealed+carry+reciprocity+act"%5D​%7D
IF this is the same bill that "be eligible to carry a conceled firearm in, his or her state of residence" seems to allow anyone from a "constitutional carry" state to carry with just their drivers license.

thread.title: GUN FOR HIRE – interview with Tyneside bassist Ed Thomas | ALIKIVI
thread.title_full: GUN FOR HIRE – interview with Tyneside bassist Ed Thomas | ALIKIVI

posts.author: Gary Alikivi
posts.title: GUN FOR HIRE – interview with Tyneside bassist Ed Thomas | ALIKIVI
posts.text:
/ Gary Alikivi 
Where did you rehearse and when did you start playing gigs ? ‘At first we’d rehearse at low volume in various band members bedrooms, with the drummer keeping time by slapping his legs, then he graduated to using a dustbin. A couple of times we rehearsed in a garage belonging to Ginger’s parents. I was 18 when I played my first gig with The Cups a bit of a South Shields supergroup that lasted until ’86. Guitarist Ginger and Stidi on drums both going on to be in The Wildhearts. Then I joined Gunslinger in ’88 and we used Baker Street Studio in Jarrow to rehearse until our singer Macca’s brother opened The Rock In , also in Jarrow. I lasted in them till 1990’. 
How did you get involved in playing music ? ‘When I was fourteen myself and most of my friends all wanted to play guitar. It seemed that everyone did back then. I think it’s because we had nowt else to do! There were no computers or consoles and only 3 channels on the telly. All we had was music and it was only natural that we’d want to emulate our heroes’. 
Who were your influences in music ? ‘I was a massive Kiss fan and I loved Ace Frehleys loose, laid back style. Low strung Les Pauls, man, you can’t beat ’em! Although I play bass I didn’t really have any bass influences and I started playing by accident! I knew Ginger from The Wildhearts when we were 16 and he wanted a bass player for his band so he asked me to do it cos he said I was a crap guitarist. To be fair, he was right, so I suppose he was the reason I started playing bass and kept at it because I found it to be much more fun than guitar!’ 
What venues did you play ? ‘My first gigs with The Cups were at The Legion club and The Cyprus pub in South Shields, wild nights in there! There were a few great venues in Shields in the Gunslinger days, Fist drummer Harry Hill had just opened the Queen Vic and that was a favourite, always jumping! There were also Cagneys in Tyne Dock and Laceys in Laygate! Quality! Heh heh. In Sunderland there was the Old 29 of course and I think it was called The Ivy House’. Gunslinger with Ed in the middle. 
What were your experiences of recording ? ‘I only recorded a couple of times with Gunslinger . Once in ’88 at Baker Street Studio which had all the cutting edge gear but we couldn’t seem to get the sound we were looking for so it was a bit of a disappointment. Tracks were Holdin’ On, She Said and Gunslinger . Then around ’89 we recorded twice in Micky Clark’s little 8 track studio in Frederick Street, South Shields and those recordings were much more successful! Much closer to the edgy feel we wanted so we done Gunslinger, Holdin’ On and She Said along with High Risk, Broken Dreams, Falling to Pieces, I Got a Feeling and I’m sure there were one or two more thats coming back to me, yes Shock Treatment, Play it from the Heart and Nothing to Show . But yeah really enjoyed that session’. 
Have you any stories from playing gigs ? ‘The Ivy House in Sunderland! I think we were the first band they’d had on there so they had no idea what to expect. We got in trouble for parking outside. The landlord wouldn’t let us use the front door so we had to go in through the cellar and up the steps into the bar, and he nearly had kittens when he saw our gear. He said ‘that lot looks far too loud for in here’. It was only a little place so we stashed our guitar cases in the cellar and by the end of the night we’d had enough hassle from the fella so we filled our cases with cans from the cellar and carried our guitars out separately!’ 
What are you doing now and are you still involved with music ? ‘I had an 8 year break from music after Gunslinger . I got a proper job and everything! Back in 2000 though I felt the urge and to be honest it never really went away. I’ve been in cover bands ever since, Kneejerk Reaction around 2003-09 then The Enzymes until 2013, Horizon from 2012-16, The Rawmones for one year in 2012 and at the moment I’m playing in Andromeda and The Spacehoppers , as well as helping out with my mates PA hire business. I’ll be involved with music til the day I drop!’ 
Interview by Gary Alikivi 2017. Share this:

posts.text:
Ow! That was my feelings! : feckingmorons: Flappyhead: As another Farker pointed out, this will result in a race to the bottom in CCW permits. That is not a good thing.
No, actually it won't. Look at the reciprocity now, my Florida permit is valid in 37 states. It isn't valid in: California, Connecticut, DC, Hawaii, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, NJ, NY, Oregon, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, Washington, or Wisconsin.
Bear in mind that Alaska, Arizona, Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, Vermont, West Virginia don't require permits to exercise your rights, as it should be.
So I can go to more that 89% of the land in the US with my permit. I don't see how bring up the missing 11% will cause what you expect.
Also a California resident for example, can carry a gun in Florida simply by getting a non-resident permit from the State of Florida. The requirements are the same as Florida residents, but non-resident permits don't have all the same reciprocity as resident permits do. A non-resident Florida permit issued to the fellow from California is good only in 32 states and certainly not California.
I'm glad my land is not ok for your untrained ass to be carrying on.
//Mandatory training and background check or drive around.
I've had mandatory classroom and didactic training and passed and FBI fingerprint based background check.
As has everyone else in Florida with a Class W permit.

feckingmorons : Ow! That was my feelings!: feckingmorons: Flappyhead: As another Farker pointed out, this will result in a race to the bottom in CCW permits. That is not a good thing.
No, actually it won't. Look at the reciprocity now, my Florida permit is valid in 37 states. It isn't valid in: California, Connecticut, DC, Hawaii, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, NJ, NY, Oregon, Puerto Rico, Rhode Island, Washington, or Wisconsin.
Bear in mind that Alaska, Arizona, Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Missouri, New Hampshire, Vermont, West Virginia don't require permits to exercise your rights, as it should be.
So I can go to more that 89% of the land in the US with my permit. I don't see how bring up the missing 11% will cause what you expect.
Also a California resident for example, can carry a gun in Florida simply by getting a non-resident permit from the State of Florida. The requirements are the same as Florida residents, but non-resident permits don't have all the same reciprocity as resident permits do. A non-resident Florida permit issued to the fellow from California is good only in 32 states and certainly not California.
I'm glad my land is not ok for your untrained ass to be carrying on.
//Mandatory training and background check or drive around.
I've had mandatory classroom and didactic training and passed and FBI fingerprint based background check.
As has everyone else in Florida with a Class W permit.
'Florida man' is a meme for a reason. The cwp process is less stringent that the orientation for a Walmart cart pusher.

Jim_Callahan : I mean... it's just license reciprocity. Literally the most common form of federalism since forever.
This is the same reason you can marry someone in Kansas, drive to Nebraska, and yet somehow you're still married and still legally allowed to drive the car. Licenses and contracts are typically supposed to cross state lines to at least some extent.
The part that the NRA assholes aren't going to like is that this is going to fairly quickly result in CCPs having the same federal oversight and standardization as drivers' licenses, too. Wyoming can basically kiss its 'shall issue' permits with no training requirement goodbye.
There isn't too much federal oversight in DLs that aren't Commercial DLs, Sure the Real ID Act set some standards for the physical card and docs needed to get it, but some states let you get a learners permit at 15, some it is 16, NYC you can't drive until 18. Some require you to still know the arm signals for turns and stop, some don't.
Some require a road test for new residents with a valid out of state license, most don't.
There is a national driver compact that helps keep track of tickets and such. If you get a ticket in TX and live in NY the points go on your NY license. If they suspend your license in Iowa for DUI, then your Vermont license is suspended. So in that state there will be interstate cooperation, but no Federal standard setting.

posts.author: Karen Guregian
posts.title: Guregian: Josh McDaniels’ talent will be on display Monday
posts.text:
Guregian: Josh McDaniels’ talent will be on display Monday Karen Guregian Thursday, December 07, 2017 Credit: Matt West POINTING THE WAY: Patriots offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels gestures during yesterday’s indoor practice in Foxboro. comments FOXBORO — If Josh McDaniels isn’t the hottest name on the coaching market heading into the Patriots’ prime-time clash with the Dolphins, he might be on the top of everyone’s list by the time he leaves South Florida.
Monday night’s game should be a nationally televised showcase of the offensive coordinator’s talents. If the New York Giants or any other team with a vacancy isn’t already impressed with his abilities, McDaniels has another opportunity to strut his stuff.
Consider the variables.
The Patriots are down an all-world tight end thanks to Rob Gronkowski’s one-game suspension. That leaves McDaniels drawing up plays without his best offensive weapon. He also might not have wide receiver Chris Hogan, who hasn’t played since Oct. 29 because of a shoulder injury. Hogan practiced for the first time yesterday, so he’s a question mark. Then there’s the uncertainty on the offensive line, where the Pats might be down to his third-string right tackle.
Put all that together with the fact the Patriots are facing the Dolphins for the second time in three weeks, and it gets a little tricky.
As we’ve seen through the years, however, McDaniels is creative, especially when up against a wall.
When he didn’t have Tom Brady and Jimmy Garoppolo last season, he came up with a plan for third-string quarterback Jacoby Brissett, a rookie making his first start, to beat Houston.
Already this season, he had receiver Julian Edelman taken away and had to adjust his game plans accordingly, without his best chain-mover. He also had to incorporate a deep threat in Brandin Cooks and discover the types of plays that fit him best. The wideout enters Monday night’s game with 53 receptions, second on the team to Gronkowski. McDaniels masterfully has weaved his stable of running backs into the offense, using them to attack on the ground and out of the backfield as receivers.
So even before taking the field against the Dolphins, McDaniels’ stock is high. He might already be the leader in the clubhouse in New York, especially if the Giants first hire Nick Caserio as general manager.
And if that doesn’t happen, everything he does from here on out just enhances the resume since his first failed attempt as a head coach in Denver. As the saying goes, it’s all gravy.
He has five Super Bowl rings, two as an offensive coordinator. Sure, he has Brady running the show, but the flow and feel of the Patriots offense is directed by McDaniels.
“He’s been doing it for a long time. Our whole team has a lot of faith in the game plans he throws out there every week. We really believe in him,” wide receiver Danny Amendola said. “Whatever pieces he has, he’s going to put our guys in the best position to make our guys successful. We do a good job as a team and as an offense buying into that.”
His mission against the Dolphins, who were successful getting in to Brady two weeks ago — either sacking him or beating him up (eight quarterback hits) — is to prevent that scenario from happening again, this time without Gronk, his best run blocker, pass protector and target in the short passing game.
Still, McDaniels will dial something up, whether it’s using his running backs more, which worked well in the first meeting, or having Brady rely on the short passing game and get rid of the ball quickly.
“He’s an awesome coach. I’m sure glad to play with him,” left tackle Nate Solder said of McDaniels. “Life’s never without its adversity. We go into whatever situation to do the best we can. We don’t make excuses, we don’t find reasons to beat ourselves, we just play the best we can whatever the situation is.”
Cooks also is a believer and will be confident in whatever McDaniels draws up for Monday night.
“He does such a great job, working with the pieces of the puzzle he has and putting it all together. You have to commend him for that,” Cooks said. “It’s not an easy job, but he comes in here and works hard at it. It’s great to have him as the OC.”
Their brief sideline spat in Buffalo notwithstanding, Brady loves having him, too. He knows McDaniels is on everyone’s radar, and if he isn’t, he should be.
Monday night is just one more chance for him to shine.

thread.title: Have Your Cake and Eat it Too Christian!
thread.title_full: Have Your Cake and Eat it Too Christian!

posts.author: Debra Seiling (noreply@blogger.com)
posts.title: Have Your Cake and Eat it Too Christian!
posts.text:
Matthew 6: 14 For if ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you: 15 But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses. 

I really struggle with this passage a lot. I guess I'm a Have Your Cake and Eat it Too Christian! I want Christ to forgive me for all my many flaws, trespasses, and vices, but I want to stay angry with those you are rude and insensitive to me.  

This passage reminds me that I can't have it both ways. I can choose to stay angry with people who have wronged me knowing that I might not be forgiven for my many, many trespasses. Or, I can work harder at turning that anger over to Christ, knowing He's already layed the ground work for my forgiveness. 

So, just how do you do that? It's easier in some situations, but in others it's down-right hard to let go of the anger! The thing is, when I'm holding on to anger toward anyone, I feel the urge to eat things I don't normally eat and at times that I don't usually eat.  Lately, I've been praying for God to have me be more open to being gracious to others, despite their actions. I also pray when the event happens. It's working, but I need to keep remembering to turn it over to Christ's very capable hands. I can't slip up and forget to add this to my daily prayers each day or I fall back into my old routine.  Matthew 6: 14 For if ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you: 15 But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses. 

Since this is an example of the positive influence God has made on my walk with Christ, this may not reflect the whole meaning of the Bible verses .
